title: Pedvax HIB (PF) Intramuscular: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Pedvax HIB (PF) intramuscular on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) helps protect young children from [Haemophilus influenzae type b](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/hib-h-influenzae-type-b-vaccine) (Hib) infection. Hib is a [bacterial infection](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/bacterial-and-viral-infections) that can cause serious illness, including [brain](www.webmd.com/brain/picture-of-the-brain-vue3) infection ( [meningitis](https://www.webmd.com/children/understanding-meningitis-basics)). Children younger than age 5 are at highest risk for infection. Vaccination is the best way to protect against this life-threatening disease. [Vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) work by causing the body to produce its own protection ( [antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/baby/antibody-testing)).This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) is not usually used by children over the age of 4 or in adults. How to use PEDVAXHIB Vial Read all [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) information available from your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional before receiving the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you have any questions, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional. This [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) is given by injection into a muscle by a health care professional. It is usually given in the upper thigh, or in the upper arm in older children. A series of injections is needed to provide the best protection. It is very important that your child receive all the injections ordered by the health care professional, or the vaccine may not work as well. Keep all scheduled medical appointments. [Vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) are usually given in a series of doses to provide the best protection. Closely follow the vaccination schedule provided by your health care professional. Keep all scheduled medical appointments. It may be helpful to mark a calendar as a reminder. There are various combinations of [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) available. Based on your age, vaccination history, and previous reaction to vaccines, your health care professional will decide which vaccines are best for you. Discuss the risks and benefits of vaccination with your health care professional. Hib vaccine can be given at the same time as the other usual childhood [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) (such as [diphtheria](https://www.webmd.com/vaccines/tdap-vaccine-for-adults)/ [tetanus](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/understanding-tetanus-basics)/ [pertussis](https://www.webmd.com/children/whooping-cough-symptoms-treatment), [hepatitis](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/understanding-hepatitis-basics), [polio](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/polio-vaccine-ipv)) either in the same injection or using a separate needle and injection site, depending on the types of vaccine being given. Side Effects Pain, swelling, and redness at the injection site may occur. Drowsiness, irritability/crying, loss of appetite, [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), fever, or [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting) may also occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, notify the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional promptly. Rarely, some people have symptoms such as [fainting](https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-fainting-basics), [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes, or [ringing in the ears](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-tinnitus-basics) just after getting a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) injection. Tell the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional right away if your child has any of these symptoms. Sitting or lying down may help, since these symptoms usually don't last long. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because the health care professional has judged that the benefit to your child is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Get medical help right away if your child has any very serious side effects, including: little or no response to touch, weak/floppy muscles. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the Vaccine Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before receiving this vaccination, tell the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if your child is allergic to it or to any other [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation); or if your child has any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as latex found in some brands), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before receiving this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell your health care professional your child's medical history, especially of: [high fever](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/fevers-causes-symptoms-treatments), moderate/severe acute illness, history of [Guillain](https://www.webmd.com/brain/what-is-guillain-barre)-Barre syndrome, [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment), vaccination history including previous reactions to any [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). Patients with [Hodgkin's disease](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-hodgkins-disease-basic-information) should receive the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) at least 10-14 days before beginning treatment or wait at least 3 months after [chemotherapy](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/chemotherapy-what-to-expect) is stopped. This vaccine is not recommended for use during pregnancy and is not usually used by adults. It is unknown if this vaccine passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. This vaccine is not usually used by adults. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) include: drugs that This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) may interfere with certain lab tests, possibly causing false test results. Make sure lab personnel and all your child's [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professionals know if your child has recently been vaccinated. Overdose Not applicable. Consult the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional about the temporary use of [acetaminophen](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-362/acetaminophen+oral/details) to treat pain and fever due to this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). There are various combinations of [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) available. Based on your child's age, vaccination history, and previous reaction to [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional will determine the most appropriate vaccines. Discuss the risks and benefits of vaccination with your health care professional. History of infection with Hib does not always protect against future infections with Hib bacteria. Your child should still receive this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) if your health care professional orders it. It is important to receive each vaccination as scheduled. Be sure to make a note of when the vaccination was last given for your child's medical record. Store in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Protect from light. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
